Expectation1: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation1: The planning session is informal, and the timeline can still shift without major impact
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I glance at my phone, the project planning session is running late, but it’s still informal—my team expects me to give a rough estimate for the new feature. I know the timeline isn’t set in stone yet, but my input will shape the next steps. Just as I’m about to chime in, I get called to the front of the polling station. The election official’s voice is firm: “There’s a registration mismatch. You’ll need to fill out a provisional ballot form, and we close in ten minutes.” I nod, heart pounding. As an engineer, I’m supposed to be reliable, present, and precise, even in these early planning stages. But as a voter, I have a civic duty to follow every instruction, to make sure my voice counts. My team is waiting for my answer, but the official is waiting for my paperwork. I feel the pressure mounting from both sides—my professional responsibility tugging at me, my civic responsibility demanding my attention. I can’t be in two places at once, and I can’t let either side down.
